mātarī.comments: The word 'mātarī' is in the locative singular, indicating 'about mother' in the given context.

anuyyutaṃ.comments: The word 'anuyyutaṃ' is a past participle formed from the root √yu with prefixes 'anu' and 'ud'. In the given context, it is used adverbially to mean 'naturally' or 'following along', indicating that the speech is in accordance with the meaning without force or affectation.
anuyyutaṃ.translation_1: He doesn’t neglect the meaning and speaks naturally.

cūḷavaggapāḷi.meaning_2: The canonical text of the Small Division
cūḷavaggapāḷi.comments: This is a sandhi compound combining 'cūḷavagga' (Small Division) and 'pāḷi' (canonical text). In the given context, it refers specifically to the canonical text of the Small Division section of the Vinaya Piṭaka.
cūḷavaggapāḷi.translation_1: The canonical text of the Small Division is finished.

paṇḍukalohitakā.meaning_2: monks Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka; the pair of monks named Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka
paṇḍukalohitakā.comments: This is a sandhi compound combining the names of two monks, Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka, who are frequently mentioned together in the Vinaya as troublemakers in the Sangha. The compound is treated as a dual entity in the text.
paṇḍukalohitakā.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena paṇḍukalohitakā bhikkhū attanā bhaṇḍanakārakā kalahakārakā vivādakārakā bhassakārakā saṅghe adhikaraṇakārakā, yepi caññe bhikkhū bhaṇḍanakārakā kalahakārakā vivādakārakā bhassakārakā saṅghe adhikaraṇakārakā te upasaṅkamitvā evaṁ vadanti—
paṇḍukalohitakā.translation_1: At that time the monks Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka were quarrelsome, argumentative, and creators of legal issues in the Sangha. They went to other monks who were also quarrelsome, argumentative, and creators of legal issues in the Sangha, and said to them,
paṇḍukalohitakā.example_2: “kathañhi nāma paṇḍukalohitakā bhikkhū attanā bhaṇḍanakārakā kalahakārakā vivādakārakā bhassakārakā saṅghe adhikaraṇakārakā, yepi caññe bhikkhū bhaṇḍanakārakā kalahakārakā vivādakārakā bhassakārakā saṅghe adhikaraṇakārakā te upasaṅkamitvā evaṁ vakkhanti—
paṇḍukalohitakā.translation_2: “How can the monks Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka act like this?”

balavābalavaṃ.comments: The word appears to be a reduplicated form of 'balavant' (strong, powerful), emphasizing intensity or repetition of the action. In context, it suggests arguing back with repeated or sustained force.

bahussutatarā.meaning_2: very learned; well educated; knowledgeable; lit. much heard
bahussutatarā.comments: The word 'bahussutatarā' is the comparative form of 'bahussuta', meaning 'more learned' or 'more knowledgeable'. It is used in the context of comparing the knowledge or learning of two entities, indicating a higher degree in one compared to the other.
bahussutatarā.example_1: Tumhe tena paṇḍitatarā ca byattatarā ca bahussutatarā ca alamattatarā ca.
bahussutatarā.translation_1: You’re wiser, more competent, more learned, and more capable than he.
bahussutatarā.example_2: Tumhe tena paṇḍitatarā ca byattatarā ca bahussutatarā ca alamattatarā ca.

alamattatarā.meaning_2: personally able; personally capable; self competent; lit. able self
alamattatarā.comments: The word 'alamattatarā' is the comparative form of 'alamatta', meaning 'more capable' or 'more competent'. In the given context, it is used to compare the capabilities of 'you' (tumhe) with 'him' (tena). The construction 'alaṃ + atta' literally means 'able self', emphasizing personal capability or competence.
alamattatarā.example_1: Tumhe tena paṇḍitatarā ca byattatarā ca bahussutatarā ca alamattatarā ca.
alamattatarā.translation_1: You’re wiser, more competent, more learned, and more capable than he.
alamattatarā.example_2: Tumhe tena paṇḍitatarā ca byattatarā ca bahussutatarā ca alamattatarā ca.

paṇḍukalohitake.meaning_2: name of one of the group of six monks; lit. yellowish-red
paṇḍukalohitake.comments: This is a compound of two names (paṇḍuka and lohitaka), both referring to members of the group of six monks. The compound likely retains the combined meaning or refers to a specific individual within that group.

paṇḍukalohitakānaṃ.comments: This is a sandhi compound combining the names of two monks, Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka, in the genitive plural form. The context shows it refers to the monks against whom a legal procedure is being enacted.
paṇḍukalohitakānaṃ.example_1: “tena hi, bhikkhave, saṅgho paṇḍukalohitakānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ tajjanīyakammaṁ karotu.
paṇḍukalohitakānaṃ.translation_1: “Well then, monks, the Sangha should do a legal procedure of condemnation against the monks Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka.
paṇḍukalohitakānaṃ.example_2: Yadi saṅghassa pattakallaṁ, saṅgho paṇḍukalohitakānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ tajjanīyakammaṁ kareyya.
paṇḍukalohitakānaṃ.translation_2: If the Sangha is ready, it should do a legal procedure of condemnation against the monks Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka.

adhammakammadvādasakaṃ.meaning_2: group of twelve on illegitimate legal procedures; set of twelve concerning unlawful actions
adhammakammadvādasakaṃ.comments: This term refers to a specific set of twelve illegitimate legal procedures in the Vinaya context, often related to disciplinary actions against monks. The contextual sentences show it being used in the conclusion of sections discussing various types of illegitimate procedures (reconciliation, ejection for offenses, etc.).
adhammakammadvādasakaṃ.translation_1: The group of twelve on illegitimate legal procedures is finished.
adhammakammadvādasakaṃ.translation_2: The group of twelve on illegitimate legal procedures is finished.

duvūpasantañca.meaning_2: improperly disposed of; not properly resolved; difficult to settle
duvūpasantañca.comments: The term 'duvūpasanta' is used in the context of legal procedures (kamma) in the Vinaya, indicating that the procedure is not properly settled or resolved. The prefix 'du-' adds a negative or difficult connotation, implying that the procedure is flawed or hard to settle.
duvūpasantañca.example_1: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgataṁ tajjanīyakammaṁ adhammakammañca hoti, avinayakammañca, duvūpasantañca.
duvūpasantañca.translation_1: “When a legal procedure of condemnation has three qualities, it’s illegitimate, contrary to the Monastic Law, and improperly disposed of:
duvūpasantañca.example_2: imehi kho, bhikkhave, tīhaṅgehi samannāgataṁ tajjanīyakammaṁ adhammakammañca hoti, avinayakammañca, duvūpasantañca.

acodetvā.meaning_2: not having accused; not having reproved
acodetvā.comments: The prefix 'a-' negates the verb 'codeti', resulting in 'not having accused'. This form is used in Vinaya contexts to describe actions taken without proper accusation or reproof.
acodetvā.example_1: Acodetvā kataṁ hoti, asāretvā kataṁ hoti, āpattiṁ anāropetvā kataṁ hoti—
acodetvā.translation_1: it’s done without having accused the person of their offense, it’s done without having reminded the person of their offense, it’s done without having charged the person with their offense.
acodetvā.example_2: Acodetvā kataṁ hoti, adhammena kataṁ hoti, vaggena kataṁ hoti—
acodetvā.translation_2: it’s done without having accused the person of their offense, it’s done illegitimately, it’s done by an incomplete assembly.

asāretvā.meaning_2: without having reminded; not having reminded
asāretvā.comments: The word 'asāretvā' is the absolutive form of 'na sāreti', meaning 'not having reminded'. In the context of the sentences provided, it is used to describe actions taken without reminding the person of their offense, indicating an incomplete or illegitimate procedure.
asāretvā.example_1: Acodetvā kataṁ hoti, asāretvā kataṁ hoti, āpattiṁ anāropetvā kataṁ hoti—
asāretvā.translation_1: it’s done without having accused the person of their offense, it’s done without having reminded the person of their offense, it’s done without having charged the person with their offense.
asāretvā.example_2: Asāretvā kataṁ hoti, adhammena kataṁ hoti, vaggena kataṁ hoti—
asāretvā.translation_2: it’s done without having reminded the person of their offense, it’s done illegitimately, it’s done by an incomplete assembly.

anāropetvā.meaning_2: without having charged; without having attributed to
anāropetvā.comments: The word is used in the context of monastic procedures, specifically referring to actions taken without formally charging someone with an offense. The negation 'na' combined with 'āropetvā' (having charged) gives the meaning of 'without having charged.'
anāropetvā.example_1: Acodetvā kataṁ hoti, asāretvā kataṁ hoti, āpattiṁ anāropetvā kataṁ hoti—
anāropetvā.translation_1: it’s done without having accused the person of their offense, it’s done without having reminded the person of their offense, it’s done without having charged the person with their offense.
anāropetvā.example_2: Āpattiṁ anāropetvā kataṁ hoti, adhammena kataṁ hoti, vaggena kataṁ hoti—
anāropetvā.translation_2: it’s done without having charged the person with their offense, it’s done illegitimately, it’s done by an incomplete assembly.”

dhammakammadvādasakaṃ.meaning_2: group of twelve on legitimate legal procedures; set of twelve legal procedures
dhammakammadvādasakaṃ.comments: The term refers to a specific set of twelve legal procedures in the Vinaya, as seen in the context of reconciliation, ejection for offenses, etc.
dhammakammadvādasakaṃ.translation_1: The group of twelve on legitimate legal procedures is finished.
dhammakammadvādasakaṃ.translation_2: The group of twelve on legitimate legal procedures is finished.

ākaṅkhamānachakkaṃ.meaning_2: group of six on wishing; hexad concerning desire
ākaṅkhamānachakkaṃ.comments: The compound refers to a set of six rules or cases related to the act of wishing or desiring, particularly in the context of Vinaya (monastic discipline). It appears in contexts discussing legal procedures like ejection for not recognizing an offense or not giving up a bad view.
ākaṅkhamānachakkaṃ.translation_1: The group of six on wishing is finished.
ākaṅkhamānachakkaṃ.translation_2: The group of six on wishing is finished.

aṭṭhārasavattaṃ.meaning_2: eighteen kinds of conduct; eighteen procedures
aṭṭhārasavattaṃ.comments: The term refers to the eighteen specific procedures or conducts in the Vinaya legal context, as seen in the sentences provided. It combines the cardinal number 'aṭṭhārasa' (eighteen) with 'vatta' (conduct, procedure).
aṭṭhārasavattaṃ.translation_1: The eighteen kinds of conduct in regard to the legal procedure of condemnation are finished.
aṭṭhārasavattaṃ.translation_2: The eighteen kinds of conduct in regard to the legal procedure of demotion are finished.

savacanīyaṃ.meaning_2: should be directed; should be instructed; should be admonished
savacanīyaṃ.comments: The term 'savacanīya' appears in the context of directing or instructing monks, often with a sense of admonishment or correction. The prefix 'sa-' implies a sense of 'with' or 'having,' possibly intensifying the meaning of 'vacanīya' (to be said or instructed).
savacanīyaṃ.translation_1: He shouldn’t direct a regular monk.
savacanīyaṃ.example_2: Pakatattassa bhikkhuno uposathaṁ ṭhapeti, pavāraṇaṁ ṭhapeti, savacanīyaṁ karoti, anuvādaṁ paṭṭhapeti, okāsaṁ kāreti, codeti, sāreti, bhikkhūhi sampayojeti—
savacanīyaṃ.translation_2: he cancels the observance-day ceremony of a regular monk; he cancels the invitation ceremony of a regular monk; he directs a regular monk; he gives instructions to a regular monk; he gets permission from a regular monk to correct him; he accuses a regular monk of an offense; he reminds a regular monk of an offense; he associates inappropriately with other monks.”

sampayojetabbanti.meaning_2: should be associated with; should be joined with
sampayojetabbanti.comments: The form 'sampayojetabba' is a gerundive (potential participle) indicating obligation or necessity, here used in a prohibitive context ('should not be associated with'). The root √yuj (to yoke, join) with causative formation gives the sense of 'causing to join/associate'.
sampayojetabbanti.translation_1: He shouldn’t associate inappropriately with other monks.”
sampayojetabbanti.translation_2: He shouldn’t associate inappropriately with other monks.”

nappaṭippassambhetabbaaṭṭhārasakaṃ.meaning_2: group of eighteen on not to be lifted; group of eighteen on not to be annulled
nappaṭippassambhetabbaaṭṭhārasakaṃ.comments: The term refers to a specific set of eighteen cases or rules that should not be lifted or annulled, as seen in the context of Vinaya (monastic discipline). The construction involves negation (na), the potential participle (paṭippassambhetabba), and the numeral (aṭṭhārasaka).
nappaṭippassambhetabbaaṭṭhārasakaṃ.translation_1: The group of eighteen on not to be lifted is finished.
nappaṭippassambhetabbaaṭṭhārasakaṃ.translation_2: The group of eighteen on not to be lifted is finished.

paṭippassambhetu.comments: The verb 'paṭippassambhetu' is an imperative form used in the context of legal procedures (kamma) in the Vinaya. It instructs the Sangha to revoke or lift a previously imposed legal action. The root is √śrambh, with prefixes 'paṭi' and 'pra', indicating a reversal or undoing of an action.
paṭippassambhetu.example_1: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, saṅgho paṇḍukalohitakānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ tajjanīyakammaṁ paṭippassambhetu.
paṭippassambhetu.translation_1: “Well then, lift that legal procedure of condemnation against the monks Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka.
paṭippassambhetu.example_2: “Tena hi, bhikkhave, saṅgho seyyasakassa bhikkhuno niyassakammaṁ paṭippassambhetu.
paṭippassambhetu.translation_2: “Well then, lift that legal procedure of demotion against the monk Seyyasaka.”

nappaṭippassambhetabbaṃ.meaning_2: should not be lifted; should not be calmed down; should not be subsided
nappaṭippassambhetabbaṃ.comments: The word is a potential participle (ptp) formed from the verb 'paṭippassambhati' meaning 'to calm down, to subside, to lift (a legal procedure)'. In the context of the sentences, it refers to legal procedures (kamma) that should not be lifted or revoked due to the monk's unwholesome qualities.
nappaṭippassambhetabbaṃ.example_1: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgatassa bhikkhuno tajjanīyakammaṁ nappaṭippassambhetabbaṁ.
nappaṭippassambhetabbaṃ.translation_1: When a monk has five qualities, a legal procedure of condemnation against him shouldn’t be lifted:
nappaṭippassambhetabbaṃ.example_2: imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgatassa bhikkhuno tajjanīyakammaṁ nappaṭippassambhetabbaṁ.

paṭippassambhetabbaaṭṭhārasakaṃ.meaning_2: group of eighteen on to be lifted; group of eighteen to be annulled
paṭippassambhetabbaaṭṭhārasakaṃ.comments: The word is a compound consisting of 'paṭippassambhetabba' (to be lifted/annulled) and 'aṭṭhārasaka' (group of eighteen). It refers to a specific set of eighteen items or rules that are to be annulled or lifted, as seen in the context of Vinaya procedures.
paṭippassambhetabbaaṭṭhārasakaṃ.translation_1: The group of eighteen on to be lifted is finished.
paṭippassambhetabbaaṭṭhārasakaṃ.translation_2: The group of eighteen on to be lifted is finished.

paṭippassambhetabbaṃ.meaning_2: should be lifted; should be calmed down; should be eased
paṭippassambhetabbaṃ.comments: The word is used in the context of legal procedures (kamma) being lifted or calmed down when a monk possesses certain qualities. It carries a sense of resolution or easing of a formal disciplinary action.
paṭippassambhetabbaṃ.example_1: Pañcahi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgatassa bhikkhuno tajjanīyakammaṁ paṭippassambhetabbaṁ.
paṭippassambhetabbaṃ.translation_1: “When a monk has five qualities, a legal procedure of condemnation against him should be lifted:
paṭippassambhetabbaṃ.example_2: imehi kho, bhikkhave, pañcahaṅgehi samannāgatassa bhikkhuno tajjanīyakammaṁ paṭippassambhetabbaṁ.

paṇḍukalohitakehi.meaning_2: name of the monks Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka
paṇḍukalohitakehi.comments: This is a compound of two proper names (Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka) in the instrumental plural, referring to two monks who were part of the 'group of six' (chaḷabhiññā) known for their misconduct.
paṇḍukalohitakehi.example_1: Tehi, bhikkhave, paṇḍukalohitakehi bhikkhūhi saṅghaṁ upasaṅkamitvā ekaṁsaṁ uttarāsaṅgaṁ karitvā vuḍḍhānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ pāde vanditvā ukkuṭikaṁ nisīditvā añjaliṁ paggahetvā evamassa vacanīyo—
paṇḍukalohitakehi.translation_1: After approaching the Sangha, the monks Paṇḍuka and Lohitaka should arrange their upper robes over one shoulder, pay respect at the feet of the senior monks, squat on their heels, raise their joined palms, and say,

paṭikassantā.meaning_2: sending back; drawing back; throwing back
paṭikassantā.comments: In the context, 'paṭikassantā' refers to the monks sending the individual back to the beginning of the disciplinary process, indicating a reversal or reset in the procedure.
paṭikassantā.example_1: apissu bhikkhū pakatā parivāsaṁ dentā mūlāya paṭikassantā mānattaṁ dentā abbhentā.
paṭikassantā.translation_1: In addition, the monks regularly gave him probation, sent him back to the beginning, gave him trial periods, and rehabilitated him.
paṭikassantā.example_2: apissu bhikkhū pakatā parivāsaṁ dentā mūlāya paṭikassantā mānattaṁ dentā abbhentā”ti.

abbhentā.comments: In the context of vinaya (monastic discipline), 'abbheti' refers to the formal act of rehabilitation or readmission of a monk who has undergone probation and trial periods. The term implies restoring the monk to full standing in the monastic community.
abbhentā.example_1: apissu bhikkhū pakatā parivāsaṁ dentā mūlāya paṭikassantā mānattaṁ dentā abbhentā.
abbhentā.translation_1: In addition, the monks regularly gave him probation, sent him back to the beginning, gave him trial periods, and rehabilitated him.
abbhentā.example_2: apissu bhikkhū pakatā parivāsaṁ dentā mūlāya paṭikassantā mānattaṁ dentā abbhentā.
abbhentā.translation_2: And how can it be that the monks regularly give him probation, send him back to the beginning, give him trial periods, and rehabilitate him?

abbhentāti.meaning_2: they lead back; they bring back; they restore
abbhentāti.comments: The word appears to be a present tense verb form meaning 'they lead back' or 'they restore', used in a Vinaya context regarding the restoration of monks to their original status.
abbhentāti.example_1: apissu bhikkhū pakatā parivāsaṁ dentā mūlāya paṭikassantā mānattaṁ dentā abbhentā”ti.
abbhentāti.example_2: apissu bhikkhū pakatā parivāsaṁ dentā mūlāya paṭikassantā mānattaṁ dentā abbhentā”ti?

niyasakammaṃ.meaning_2: one's own duty; one's own work; one's own actions
niyasakammaṃ.comments: The word is a compound of 'niya' (one's own) and 'sakamma' (duty/work/actions), emphasizing personal responsibility or occupation.

vidhutikaṃ.comments: The word appears to be a neuter noun derived from the root √dhū (to shake) with the prefix vi- (indicating separation or intensity), forming a compound meaning 'shaking' or 'trembling'. The suffix -ka likely adds a diminutive or nominalizing force.

ākaṅkhamānacuddasakaṃ.meaning_2: the group of fourteen on wishing
ākaṅkhamānacuddasakaṃ.comments: The compound refers to a set of 14 verses related to the theme of wishing or desiring, as indicated by the context.
ākaṅkhamānacuddasakaṃ.translation_1: The group of fourteen on wishing is finished.

upaghātikena.comments: The word is used to describe harmful conduct, whether bodily, verbal, or both. It is derived from the root √ghaṭ with the prefix upa, indicating a sense of 'harming' or 'damaging'.
upaghātikena.example_1: Kāyikena upaghātikena samannāgato hoti, vācasikena upaghātikena samannāgato hoti, kāyikavācasikena upaghātikena samannāgato hoti—
upaghātikena.translation_1: his bodily conduct is harmful; his verbal conduct is harmful; his bodily and verbal conduct are harmful.
upaghātikena.example_2: Kāyikena upaghātikena samannāgato hoti, vācasikena upaghātikena samannāgato hoti, kāyikavācasikena upaghātikena samannāgato hoti—
upaghātikena.translation_2: his bodily conduct is harmful; his verbal conduct is harmful; his bodily and verbal conduct are harmful.

sudhammo.comments: The name 'Sudhammo' is a compound of 'su' (good) and 'dhamma' (teaching or nature), meaning 'one of good nature' or 'one who follows the good teaching'. In the context, it refers to a specific monk named Sudhamma.
sudhammo.example_1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā sudhammo macchikāsaṇḍe cittassa gahapatino āvāsiko hoti, navakammiko dhuvabhattiko.
sudhammo.translation_1: At one time Venerable Sudhamma was the staying at the householder Citta’s monastery at Macchikāsaṇḍa. He was in charge of the building work and received a regular supply of food.
sudhammo.example_2: Atha kho citto gahapati therānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ adhivāsanaṁ viditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā there bhikkhū abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā yenāyasmā sudhammo tenupasaṅkami, upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ sudhammaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
sudhammo.translation_2: When he knew that they had accepted, Citta got up from his seat, bowed down, circumambulated them with his right side toward them, and went to Sudhamma. He bowed to him

nimantetukāmo.meaning_2: wishing to invite; wanting to invite
nimantetukāmo.comments: The word is a combination of the infinitive 'nimantetuṃ' (to invite) and the adjective 'kāma' (wishing), forming a present tense verb meaning 'wishing to invite'. In the given sentences, it describes Citta's intention to invite the Sangha or individual monks.
nimantetukāmo.example_1: Yadā citto gahapati saṅghaṁ vā gaṇaṁ vā puggalaṁ vā nimantetukāmo hoti tadā na āyasmantaṁ sudhammaṁ anapaloketvā saṅghaṁ vā gaṇaṁ vā puggalaṁ vā nimanteti.
nimantetukāmo.translation_1: Whenever Citta wanted to invite the Sangha, a group of monks, or an individual monk, he would not do so without getting permission from Sudhamma.
nimantetukāmo.example_2: “pubbe khvāyaṁ citto gahapati yadā saṅghaṁ vā gaṇaṁ vā puggalaṁ vā nimantetukāmo na maṁ anapaloketvā saṅghaṁ vā gaṇaṁ vā puggalaṁ vā nimanteti;
nimantetukāmo.translation_2: “Previously when Citta wanted to invite the Sangha, a group of monks, or an individual monk, he wouldn’t do so without getting my permission.

sudhammena.meaning_2: good law; good doctrine; name of a monk
sudhammena.comments: In the context, 'sudhammena' refers to a monk named Sudhamma, who is being instructed to perform certain actions. The name itself means 'good law' or 'good doctrine', reflecting a positive attribute related to the Dhamma.
sudhammena.example_1: “Bahumhi vata, bhante, ratane buddhavacane vijjamāne ayyena sudhammena yadeva kiñci bhāsitaṁ yadidaṁ tilasaṅguḷikāti.
sudhammena.translation_1: “When there are so many jewels in the word of the Buddha, sir, you speak of sesame cookies.
sudhammena.example_2: Evameva kho, bhante, bahumhi ratane buddhavacane vijjamāne ayyena sudhammena yadeva kiñci bhāsitaṁ yadidaṁ tilasaṅguḷikā”ti.
sudhammena.translation_2: In the same way, when there are so many jewels in the word of the Buddha, you speak of sesame cookies.”

kākavassaṃ.comments: The compound 'kākavassa' refers to the sound or cry of a crow, as seen in the context where a chick attempts to imitate a crow's call.
kākavassaṃ.example_1: Yadā kho so, bhante, kukkuṭapotako kākavassaṁ vassitukāmo hoti, kākakukkuṭīti vassati;
kākavassaṃ.translation_1: When that chick wanted to caw like a crow, it cried, ‘caw-ca-doodle-doo.’

vassitukāmo.meaning_2: wishing to rain; wanting to make a sound like rain
vassitukāmo.comments: The word is a compound of 'vassitu' (infinitive of 'vassati', meaning 'to rain' or 'to make a sound like rain') and 'kāma' (meaning 'wishing' or 'wanting'). In the context, it describes the chick's desire to imitate the sounds of a crow or a rooster.
vassitukāmo.example_1: Yadā kho so, bhante, kukkuṭapotako kākavassaṁ vassitukāmo hoti, kākakukkuṭīti vassati;
vassitukāmo.translation_1: When that chick wanted to caw like a crow, it cried, ‘caw-ca-doodle-doo.’
vassitukāmo.example_2: yadā kukkuṭivassaṁ vassitukāmo hoti, kukkuṭikākāti vassati.
vassitukāmo.translation_2: And when that chick wanted to crow like a rooster, it cried, ‘cock-a-doodle-caw.’

kākakukkuṭīti.meaning_2: caw-ca-doodle-doo; the sound a chick makes when trying to imitate a crow
kākakukkuṭīti.comments: This is a sandhi compound combining 'kāka' (crow), 'kukkuṭī' (hen/chicken), and 'iti' (thus, like this). The word is used to represent the sound a chick makes when attempting to imitate a crow, showing an onomatopoeic usage in the context.
kākakukkuṭīti.example_1: Yadā kho so, bhante, kukkuṭapotako kākavassaṁ vassitukāmo hoti, kākakukkuṭīti vassati;
kākakukkuṭīti.translation_1: When that chick wanted to caw like a crow, it cried, ‘caw-ca-doodle-doo.’

kukkuṭivassaṃ.comments: The word is a sandhi compound of 'kukkuṭi' (hen/chicken) and 'vassaṃ' (rain/cry). In the given context, it refers to the sound a rooster makes, hence 'rooster's cry' or 'rooster's crowing'.
kukkuṭivassaṃ.example_1: yadā kukkuṭivassaṁ vassitukāmo hoti, kukkuṭikākāti vassati.
kukkuṭivassaṃ.translation_1: And when that chick wanted to crow like a rooster, it cried, ‘cock-a-doodle-caw.’

kukkuṭikākāti.meaning_2: cock-a-doodle-caw; imitation of a rooster's crow by a chick
kukkuṭikākāti.comments: The word is a playful onomatopoeic compound imitating a rooster's crow, formed from 'kukkuṭī' (hen/chick), 'kāka' (crow), and 'iti' (thus/like this). The context shows it's a chick attempting to crow like a rooster.
kukkuṭikākāti.example_1: yadā kukkuṭivassaṁ vassitukāmo hoti, kukkuṭikākāti vassati.
kukkuṭikākāti.translation_1: And when that chick wanted to crow like a rooster, it cried, ‘cock-a-doodle-caw.’

tilasaṃguḷikāti.meaning_2: sesame ball; sesame pill; sesame globule
tilasaṃguḷikāti.comments: The word is a compound of 'tila' (sesame) and 'saṃguḷikā' (ball/pill), referring to a small ball or pill made of sesame.

sudhammassa.meaning_2: name of a monk; lit. 'good in the Dhamma'
sudhammassa.comments: The word 'sudhammassa' is the dative/genitive singular form of 'sudhammo', referring to a monk named Sudhamma. The name literally means 'good in the Dhamma' (su + dhamma). In the context, it appears in legal procedures against this monk.
sudhammassa.translation_1: I’ll do my best to provide you with robe-cloth, almsfood, a dwelling, and medicinal supplies.”
sudhammassa.example_2: “tena hi, bhikkhave, saṅgho sudhammassa bhikkhuno paṭisāraṇīyakammaṁ karotu—
sudhammassa.translation_2: “Well then, do a legal procedure of reconciliation against the monk Sudhamma,

ākaṅkhamānacatukkaṃ.meaning_2: group of four on wishing; tetrad concerning desire
ākaṅkhamānacatukkaṃ.comments: The compound refers to a set of four items related to the concept of wishing or desiring, as indicated by the context where it is described as being 'finished' (niṭṭhitaṁ).
ākaṅkhamānacatukkaṃ.translation_1: The group of four on wishing is finished.

avijahāpetvā.meaning_2: having not caused to give up; having not made abandon; without abandoning
avijahāpetvā.comments: The word is a negative absolutive form (avijahāpetvā) derived from the causative of √hā (to abandon), with the prefix 'a-' (not) and 'vi-' (apart). In the context, it means 'without abandoning' or 'not causing to give up' the sight and hearing of Citta.
avijahāpetvā.example_1: No ce khamati, anudūtena bhikkhunā sudhammo bhikkhu cittassa gahapatino dassanūpacāraṁ avijahāpetvā savanūpacāraṁ avijahāpetvā ekaṁsaṁ uttarāsaṅgaṁ kārāpetvā ukkuṭikaṁ nisīdāpetvā añjaliṁ paggaṇhāpetvā taṁ āpattiṁ desāpetabbo”ti.
avijahāpetvā.translation_1: If not, then within sight and hearing of Citta, the monk Sudhamma should arrange his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and confess that offense.”
avijahāpetvā.example_2: No ce khamati, anudūtena bhikkhunā sudhammo bhikkhu cittassa gahapatino dassanūpacāraṁ avijahāpetvā savanūpacāraṁ avijahāpetvā ekaṁsaṁ uttarāsaṅgaṁ kārāpetvā ukkuṭikaṁ nisīdāpetvā añjaliṁ paggaṇhāpetvā taṁ āpattiṁ desāpetabbo”ti.
avijahāpetvā.translation_2: If not, then within sight and hearing of Citta, the monk Sudhamma should arrange his upper robe over one shoulder, squat on his heels, raise his joined palms, and confess that offense.”

asambhogaṃ.meaning_2: prohibiting from living with; prohibiting from interacting with
asambhogaṃ.comments: The term 'asambhogaṃ' is consistently used in the context of prohibiting someone from living or interacting with the Sangha, indicating a formal disciplinary action.
asambhogaṃ.translation_1: prohibiting him from living with the Sangha.
asambhogaṃ.translation_2: prohibiting him from living with the Sangha.

tecattālīsavattaṃ.comments: The compound 'tecattālīsavattaṃ' refers to a specific set of forty-three types of conduct related to Vinaya legal procedures, particularly ejection (ukkhepanīyakamma) for various offenses.
tecattālīsavattaṃ.translation_1: The forty-three kinds of conduct in regard to the legal procedure of ejection for not recognizing an offense are finished.
tecattālīsavattaṃ.translation_2: The forty-three kinds of conduct in regard to the legal procedure of ejection for not making amends for an offense are finished.

āsanābhihāro.meaning_2: offering of a seat; presenting a seat
āsanābhihāro.comments: The compound 'āsanābhihāro' is a sandhi form combining 'āsana' (seat) and 'abhihāra' (offering). In the given context, it refers to the act of offering a seat, specifically by a regular monk to another, which is discouraged in the provided sentences.
āsanābhihāro.translation_1: He shouldn’t consent to a regular monk offering him a seat.
āsanābhihāro.translation_2: He shouldn’t consent to a regular monk offering him a seat.

seyyābhihāro.meaning_2: offering of a bed; providing bedding
seyyābhihāro.comments: The compound 'seyyābhihāro' refers to the act of offering or providing a bed, as seen in the context where a monk is not to consent to such an offering from a regular monk. The term combines 'seyyā' (bed) and 'abhihāra' (offering).
seyyābhihāro.translation_1: He shouldn’t consent to a regular monk offering him a bed.
seyyābhihāro.translation_2: He shouldn’t consent to a regular monk offering him a bed.

pattacīvarappaṭiggahaṇaṃ.meaning_2: receiving of bowl and robe; acceptance of bowl and robe
pattacīvarappaṭiggahaṇaṃ.comments: The term refers to the act of receiving or accepting the bowl and robe, which are essential items for a monk. The context shows that this action is regulated within the monastic community, especially concerning interactions between monks of different statuses.
pattacīvarappaṭiggahaṇaṃ.translation_1: He shouldn’t consent to a regular monk receiving his bowl and robe.
pattacīvarappaṭiggahaṇaṃ.example_2: Pakatattassa bhikkhuno seyyābhihāraṁ, pādodakaṁ pādapīṭhaṁ, pādakathalikaṁ, pattacīvarappaṭiggahaṇaṁ, nahāne piṭṭhiparikammaṁ sādiyati—
pattacīvarappaṭiggahaṇaṃ.translation_2: he consents to a regular monk offering him a bed; he consents to a regular monk offering him water for washing his feet and a foot stool; he consents to a regular monk offering him a foot scraper; he consents to a regular monk receiving his bowl and robe; he consents to a regular monk massaging his back when bathing.

anuddhaṃsetabbo.meaning_2: should be charged (with); should be accused (of)
anuddhaṃsetabbo.comments: The word is a potential participle (ptp) formed from the causative base of √dhaṃs with prefix anu-. In context, it refers to the act of charging or accusing someone (a monk) of various failures (in morality, conduct, etc.). The negative particle 'na' preceding it in all sentences indicates prohibition against such accusations.
anuddhaṃsetabbo.translation_1: He shouldn’t charge a regular monk with failure in morality.
anuddhaṃsetabbo.translation_2: He shouldn’t charge a regular monk with failure in conduct.

bhedetabbo.meaning_2: should be caused to split; should be divided; should be broken
bhedetabbo.comments: The word is a potential participle (ptp) derived from the causative form of √bhid ('to break, split'). In the given context, it conveys the sense of 'should not be caused to divide' among monks, emphasizing the importance of unity in the monastic community.
bhedetabbo.translation_1: He shouldn’t cause division between monks.
bhedetabbo.translation_2: He shouldn’t cause division between monks.

bhedetabbā.meaning_2: should be broken; should be split; should be divided
bhedetabbā.comments: The form 'bhedetabbā' is a feminine singular potential participle (ptp) derived from the causative 'bhedeti' (to cause to break/split). The context suggests an obligation or necessity ('should be broken/split').

bhikkhusikkhāya.comments: The compound 'bhikkhusikkhā' refers specifically to the training or discipline followed by Buddhist monks. It is a feminine noun formed by combining 'bhikkhu' (monk) and 'sikkhā' (training). The context shows it is used to describe the proper conduct and practices expected of monks.
bhikkhusikkhāya.translation_1: He should train in the monks’ training.
bhikkhusikkhāya.example_2: bhikkhū na sevati, bhikkhusikkhāya na sikkhati—
bhikkhusikkhāya.translation_2: he doesn’t associate with monks; he doesn’t train in the monks’ training.

bhikkhusikkhā.comments: A compound referring to the training or discipline specifically for Buddhist monks (bhikkhus). The term combines 'bhikkhu' (monk) and 'sikkhā' (training), emphasizing the structured practice for monastics.

nappaṭippassambhetabbatecattālīsakaṃ.meaning_2: group of forty-three on not to be lifted
nappaṭippassambhetabbatecattālīsakaṃ.comments: The word is a sandhi compound combining 'na' (not), 'paṭippassambhetabba' (to be lifted), 'te' (that), and 'cattālīsakaṃ' (group of forty). It refers to a specific group of rules or cases where a certain legal procedure (ejection) is not to be lifted.
nappaṭippassambhetabbatecattālīsakaṃ.translation_1: The group of forty-three on not to be lifted in regard to the legal procedure of ejection for not recognizing an offense is finished.
nappaṭippassambhetabbatecattālīsakaṃ.translation_2: The group of forty-three on not to be lifted in regard to the legal procedure of ejection for not making amends for an offense is finished.

nappaṭippassambhetabba.meaning_2: should not be calmed back; should not be subsided; should not be annulled
nappaṭippassambhetabba.comments: The word is a negative potential participle (ptp) formed from 'paṭippassambhati' (to calm back, subside, annul) with the negative prefix 'na'. It implies something that should not be allowed to subside or be annulled, possibly referring to a state or condition that must be maintained.

tecattālīsakaṃ.comments: A compound adjective meaning 'forty-three', formed from 'ti' (three) and 'cattālīsa' (forty) with the suffix 'ka'.

āsanābhihāraṃ.meaning_2: offering a seat; presenting a seat
āsanābhihāraṃ.comments: The compound 'āsanābhihāraṃ' is consistently translated as 'offering a seat' in the provided sentences, indicating a formal act of respect where a seat is presented to someone, particularly a monk. The context shows it as part of a series of respectful gestures.
āsanābhihāraṃ.example_1: Pakatattassa bhikkhuno abhivādanaṁ, paccuṭṭhānaṁ, añjalikammaṁ, sāmīcikammaṁ, āsanābhihāraṁ sādiyati—
āsanābhihāraṃ.translation_1: he consents to a regular monk bowing down to him; he consents to a regular monk standing up for him; he consents to a regular monk raising his joined palms to him; he consents to a regular monk doing acts of respect toward him; he consents to a regular monk offering him a seat.
āsanābhihāraṃ.example_2: Na pakatattassa bhikkhuno abhivādanaṁ, paccuṭṭhānaṁ, añjalikammaṁ, sāmīcikammaṁ, āsanābhihāraṁ sādiyati—
āsanābhihāraṃ.translation_2: he doesn’t consent to a regular monk bowing down to him; he doesn’t consent to a regular monk standing up for him; he doesn’t consent to a regular monk raising his joined palms to him; he doesn’t consent to a regular monk doing acts of respect toward him; he doesn’t consent to a regular monk offering him a seat.

seyyābhihāraṃ.comments: The compound 'seyyābhihāra' refers to the act of offering or providing a bed or bedding, as seen in the context where monks consent to or refuse such offerings from regular monks. It combines 'seyyā' (bed) and 'abhihāra' (offering).
seyyābhihāraṃ.example_1: Pakatattassa bhikkhuno seyyābhihāraṁ, pādodakaṁ pādapīṭhaṁ, pādakathalikaṁ, pattacīvarappaṭiggahaṇaṁ, nahāne piṭṭhiparikammaṁ sādiyati—
seyyābhihāraṃ.translation_1: he consents to a regular monk offering him a bed; he consents to a regular monk offering him water for washing his feet and a foot stool; he consents to a regular monk offering him a foot scraper; he consents to a regular monk receiving his bowl and robe; he consents to a regular monk massaging his back when bathing.
seyyābhihāraṃ.example_2: Na pakatattassa bhikkhuno seyyābhihāraṁ, pādodakaṁ pādapīṭhaṁ, pādakathalikaṁ, pattacīvarappaṭiggahaṇaṁ, nahāne piṭṭhiparikammaṁ sādiyati—
seyyābhihāraṃ.translation_2: he doesn’t consent to a regular monk offering him a bed; he doesn’t consent to a regular monk offering him water for washing his feet and a foot stool; he doesn’t consent to a regular monk offering him a foot scraper; he doesn’t consent to a regular monk receiving his bowl and robe; he doesn’t consent to a regular monk massaging his back when bathing.
